user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleSymbolLookup:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleSymbolLookup(osal_id_t module_id, cpuaddr *symbol_address, const char *symbol_name)
{
    int32               return_code;
    int32               staticsym_status;
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /*
    ** Check parameters
    */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(symbol_address);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(symbol_name);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, module_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_module_table, token);

        return_code = OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(&token, symbol_address, symbol_name);
        if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            /* look for a static symbol that also matches this module name */
            staticsym_status = OS_SymbolLookup_Static(symbol_address, symbol_name, record->name_entry);

            /*
             * Only overwrite the return code if static lookup was successful.
             * Otherwise keep the error code from the low level implementation.
             */
            if (staticsym_status == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                return_code = staticsym_status;
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ModuleSymbolLookup:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_module_table
...
int32 OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    int32                             status;
    OS_impl_module_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);

    status = OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(impl->dl_handle, SymbolAddress, SymbolName);

    return status;
}
...
int32 OS_SymbolLookup_Static(cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName, const char *ModuleName)
{
    int32                      return_code = OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
    OS_static_symbol_record_t *StaticSym   = OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE;

    while (StaticSym != NULL)
    {
        if (StaticSym->Name == NULL)
        {
            /* end of list --
             * Return "OS_ERROR" to indicate that an actual search was done
             * with a not-found result, vs. not searching at all. */
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }
        if (strcmp(StaticSym->Name, SymbolName) == 0 &&
            (ModuleName == NULL || strcmp(StaticSym->Module, ModuleName) == 0))
        {
            /* found matching symbol */
            *SymbolAddress = (cpuaddr)StaticSym->Address;
            return_code    = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }

        ++StaticSym;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected fragments that can affect reachability analysis because they either expand to control-flow altering constructs (macros) or depend on external/indirect state (object token/table/indexing, static symbol table) that can make code paths effectively unreachable. Specifically: - The two OS_CHECK_POINTER calls and the OS_CHECK_POINTER macro (which expands to BUGCHECK(...)) can introduce early exits/terminating behavior depending on BUGCHECK's definition; that may make subsequent code unreachable in some builds/configurations. - The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro and its uses (record = ... and impl = ...) perform index computation from the token by taking the address of the token expression; the macro's address-of usage can behave unexpectedly (or be misused by callers) and can lead to code that is never executed or that triggers undefined behavior. - The call into OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(&token, ...) hands the address of the local token; control flow inside the implementation depends on the token and the impl table lookup, which may make portions of code unreachable depending on token/table state. - The entire OS_SymbolLookup_Static function (loop and sentinel handling) is dependent on the external OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE pointer and a sentinel (Name == NULL); different definitions of that external data (NULL vs. table with sentinel) produce different reachable return branches (OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED vs OS_ERROR vs OS_SUCCESS), so the branches deserve review for unintended unreachable code. Other fragments in the provided code were not included because they represent normal, conditional control flow that does not obviously produce unreachable code in themselves (for example: the if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) block in OS_ModuleSymbolLookup, the early returns in OS_ObjectIdGetById that follow error checks, the OS_ObjectIdRelease call, and the simple return return_code at function end). Those are standard, intended control-flow patterns (early return on error, cleanup on success) and do not, by themselves, indicate unreachable code without additional context (such as macro definitions or external table values) which are already covered by the selected fragments.
